titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Radical and Labor Pamphlets Collection, 1896-1967, bulk 1911-1954 RL.11741
titlestmt.author: Rubenstein Staff

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-05-29 15:02:43 -0400.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.unittitle: Radical and Labor Pamphlets collection
did.abstract: The Radical and Labor Pamphlets Collection (1896-1967) includes approximately 720 pamphlets and other ephemeral publications relating to communism, socialism and other left-wing movements as well as to labor organizations and trade unions. There are some additional pamphlets related to anti-communist movements and some examples of Soviet propaganda.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Some of the pamphlets are rapidly deteriorating due to the acidic composition of their paper. To protect the most severe cases from further deterioration yet still make them available to researchers, many of them were photocopied on acid-free paper. These use copies are filed in the main collection and the originals are closed to use.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Radical and Labor Pamphlets Collection was transferred from Duke University's William R. Perkins Library to the Rubenstein Library in 1961.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The pamphlets are arranged by subject categories, with the largest groups relating to the activities and membership of the Communist and Socialist parties.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Radical and Labor Pamphlets Collection, 1896-1967, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Paula Jeannet, Debbera Carson, Brad Siegele, Allison Gluvna, Liz Scott, and Nicole Teal in 1997.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Pamphlet titles and other description in this collection guide were taken from a printed inventory produced in 1997.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The Radical and Labor Pamphlets Collection spans the years from 1896 to 1967, with the bulk of the dates falling between 1911 and 1954, and is made up of publications relating to communism, socialism and other left-wing movements as well as to labor parties and trade unions. Subjects represented are: the Communist Party in the U.S. and Great Britain; socialism in the U.S. and other countries; radical youth organizations; political trials and persecutions of radical activists; labor organizations; anti-fascist and pacifist movements; anarchist organizations; anti-Communist propaganda; Soviet propaganda; and Soviet-Western relations. Other significant topics include economic justice, electoral campaigns, human rights issues, the role of women and youth in activist movements, unemployment, housing, fascism in Spain and other contemporary war issues.

There are many important individual authors represented in this collection, including Israel Amter, Arthur Clegg, Georgi Dimitrov, Emma Goldman, Gilbert Green, Grace Hutchins, Mikhail Ivanovich Kalinin, Corliss Lamont, Clare Booth Luce, Philip Murray, Harry Pollitt, Karl Radek, Iosif Stalin, Lev Trotskii, and many others. Many pamphlets were produced anonymously under the aegis of institutions: these include the Communist Party, USA, Socialist Labor Party, Young Communist League, International Labor Defense, Civil Rights Congress, Communist International, Congress of Industrial Organizations, Farmer's Labor Unions, American Federation of Labor, Friends of the Soviet Union, and many more.

The pamphlets are arranged by subject categories, with the largest groups relating to the activities and membership of the Communist and Socialist parties. There is a small group of pamphlets chiefly made up of radical and labor song collections from 1912 to 1950. The majority of the pamphlets were produced in the United States and Great Britain, but there are also smaller groups of materials from Russia, India, Australia, Canada, China, Ireland, Italy, Brazil, the Philippines, and Mexico.

Many of these publications are ephemeral, that is, focused on urgent contemporary issues and generally intended for immediate consumption or short-term use. For this and for other reasons, they were often printed on poor quality paper which now shows signs of severe deterioration. The results are that few of these publications remain in circulation, and researchers may find many of them difficult to locate in library collections.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

did.unittitle: Communism, USA
Communist Party of America
Pamphlets from New York State

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically, and within date groups, alphabetically by title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Anonymous pamphlets published by the Communist Party of America in New York State. Many are related to political campaigns, but other topics include women's issues, unemployment, housing, youth programs, and World War II. Three pamphlets are not published by the Party but by Workers Library Publishers, the Party's publishing house.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Issued by the Communist Party of America or by Communist Party-affiliated publishing houses such as New Century Publishers or Workers Library Publishers. Arranged alphabetically by author. Other pamphlets by Gil Green also can be found under "Young Communist League...," of which he was president, under the series "Communism, USA, Related Organizations."

The Young Communist League and Other Related Radical Youth Organizations

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Organizations represented include the Young Communist League, the Young Pioneers of America, the International Student Union, and the Student League for Industrial Democracy. One pamphlet was issued under the auspices of the Anti-Fascist Youth Rally in Moscow, 1941. Five pamphlets were written by Gilbert Green, president of the Young Communist League.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Issued by various groups and committees in defense of the civil rights of persecuted individuals or political groups in the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Chiefly published in the U.S.. Communist and non-communist radical groups are represented. Most of the pamphlets are concerned with Nazi Germany, with fascism in Europe at large, and the threat of fascism in the U.S.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Pamphlets sponsored by various other organizations such as International Labor Defense, the International Workers of the World, and the "Wobblies" (Industrial Workers of the World), written by various authors or published anonymously. Published chiefly during the 1930s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two pamphlets are published by the organization itself, while a group of others was written by Georgi Dimitrov, the head of Communist International. Most of the pamphlets concern fascism and the party platform.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Pamphlets issued either by the Communist Parties in countries other than the U.S. or Great Britain, or pamphlets published in the U.S. that discuss communism in the world. Countries represented are Australia, Brazil, Canada, China, India, Ireland, Italy, and Mexico.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Five of these pamphlets were written by Leon Trotsky, while the other four are written by various authors and concern Trotskyism

scopecontent.p: Pamphlets by various authors concerning anarchist movements; there is also a eulogy of Emma Goldman. Pamphlets written by Emma Goldman are grouped separately.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One pamphlet was written by Eugene Debs, Socialist Party leader, and another by Jack London, American writer and social activist. Several pamphlets in this series discuss women's issues.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Pamphlets published under the auspices of the Socialist Party, USA include the Party's manifesto and a pamphlet by Eugene Debs on the Party's platform. Several publications concern labor issues, and one discusses the affinity between Catholicism and Socialism.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: All pamphlets were written by Daniel De Leon, a leader in the Socialist Labor Party. Two are debates with other politicians. Includes the Party's Constitution, published sometime after 1940.

Socialism, Other Countries

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Countries chiefly represented are Great Britain and India, but also include Canada, Australia, and various Central Eastern European countries sending delegates to a conference in Paris. Subjects are varied, and include labor issues, women's issues, Russia, the nationalization of India, and World War II. One pamphlet contains the Canadian Socialist Party's Manifesto

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Chiefly speeches by USSR government and party officials such as Stalin, Gromyko, Malenkov, Vyshinskii, Molotov, Rykov, and Litvinov. One pamphlet addresses the role of Socialist women in Russia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Pamphlets which are considered neither radical nor anti-Communist, issued in the West and discussing attitudes and relations with the Soviet Union. One pamphlet was written by Richard M. Nixon in 1959.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Original pamphlets in this series are restricted for preservation reasons. Use copies exist in the collections.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series contains original pamphlets removed from the main run of pamphlets and housed separately due to preservation concerns. Use copies of these originals are filed in the main pamphlet run and indicated with the use copy designation.

did.unittitle: Originals removed for preservation
